remixlab.proscene

Class Frame

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.proscene.Frame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    InteractiveFrame

    public class Frame
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    A Frame is a 3D coordinate system, represented by a position() and an orientation(). The order of these transformations is important: the Frame is first translated and then rotated around the new translated origin.

    In rare situations a frame can be linkTo(Frame), meaning that it will share its translation(), rotation(), referenceFrame(), and constraint() with the other frame, which can useful for some off-screen scenes.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  Frame.FrameKernel
      Internal class that holds the main frame attributes.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Frame

        public Frame()
        Creates a default Frame.

        Its position() is (0,0,0) and it has an identity orientation() Quaternion. The referenceFrame() and the constraint() are null.

      • Frame

        public Frame(processing.core.PVector p,
     Quaternion r)
        Creates a Frame with a position() and an orientation().

        See the PVector and Quaternion documentations for convenient constructors and methods.

        The Frame is defined in the world coordinate system (its referenceFrame() is null). It has a null associated constraint().

    • Method Detail

      • copy

        public Frame copy()
        Calls Frame(Frame) (which is private) and returns a copy of this object.
        See Also:
        Frame(Frame)

      • clone

        public Frame clone()
        Implementation of the clone method.

        The method performs a deep copy of the translation() and rotation() objects of the Frame, and a shallow copy of its referenceFrame() and constraint() objects.

        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        See Also:
        copy()

      • kernel

        public Frame.FrameKernel kernel()

      • setKernel

        public void setKernel(Frame.FrameKernel k)

      • translation

        public final processing.core.PVector translation()
        Returns the Frame translation, defined with respect to the referenceFrame().

        Use position() to get the result in the world coordinates. These two values are identical when the referenceFrame() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setTranslation(PVector), setTranslationWithConstraint(PVector)

      • rotation

        public final Quaternion rotation()
        Returns the Frame rotation, defined with respect to the referenceFrame() (i.e, the current Quaternion orientation).

        Use orientation() to get the result in the world coordinates. These two values are identical when the referenceFrame() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setRotation(Quaternion), setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion)

      • referenceFrame

        public final Frame referenceFrame()
        Returns the reference Frame, in which coordinates system the Frame is defined.

        The translation() rotation() of the Frame are defined with respect to the reference Frame coordinate system. A null reference Frame (default value) means that the Frame is defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use position() and orientation() to recursively convert values along the reference Frame chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference Frame null.

        Use setReferenceFrame(Frame) to set this value and create a Frame hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert 3D coordinates from one Frame to another: see coordinatesOf(PVector), localCoordinatesOf(PVector) , coordinatesOfIn(PVector, Frame) and their inverse functions.

        Vectors can also be converted using transformOf(PVector), transformOfIn(PVector, Frame), localTransformOf(PVector) and their inverse functions.

      • constraint

        public Constraint constraint()
        Returns the current constraint applied to the Frame.

        A null value (default) means that no Constraint is used to filter the Frame translation and rotation.

        See the Constraint class documentation for details.

      • listeners

        public java.util.List<KeyFrameInterpolator> listeners()
        Returns the list of KeyFrameInterpolators that are currently listening to this frame. Normally, you should not call this method as the KeyFrameInterpolator takes care of calling it.
        See Also:
        KeyFrameInterpolator.addKeyFrame(Frame, float, boolean)

      • addListener

        public void addListener(KeyFrameInterpolator kfi)
        Adds kfi to the list of KeyFrameInterpolators that are currently listening this frame.

      • removeListener

        public void removeListener(KeyFrameInterpolator kfi)
        Removes kfi from the list of KeyFrameInterpolators that are currently listening to this frame. Normally, you should not call this method, unless you have added kfi before (by calling addListener(KeyFrameInterpolator)).
        See Also:
        KeyFrameInterpolator.addKeyFrame(Frame, float, boolean)

      • linkTo

        public boolean linkTo(Frame sourceFrame)
        Links this frame (referred to as the requested frame) to sourceFrame, meaning that this frame will take (and share by reference) the translation(), rotation(), referenceFrame(), and constraint() from the sourceFrame. This can useful for some off-screen scenes, e.g., to link a frame defined in one scene to the camera frame defined in other scene (see the CameraCrane example).

        Note: Linking frames has the following properties:

        1. A frame can be linked only to another frame (referred to as the source frame).
        2. A source frame can be linked by from many (requested) frames.
        3. A source frame can't be linked to another (source) frame, i.e., it can only receive links form other frames.
        Parameters:
        sourceFrame - the frame to link this frame with.
        Returns:
        true if this frame can successfully being linked to the frame. False otherwise.
        See Also:
        linkFrom(Frame), unlink(), unlinkFrom(Frame), isLinked(), areLinkedTogether(Frame)

      • linkFrom

        public boolean linkFrom(Frame requestedFrame)
        Attempts to link the requestedFrame to this frame.

        See linkTo(Frame) for the rules and terminology applying to the linking process.

        Parameters:
        requestedFrame - the frame that is requesting a link to this frame.
        Returns:
        true if the requested frame can successfully being linked to this frame. False otherwise.
        See Also:
        linkTo(Frame), unlink(), unlinkFrom(Frame), isLinked(), areLinkedTogether(Frame)

      • unlink

        public boolean unlink()
        Unlinks this frame from its source frame. Does nothing if this frame is not linked to another frame.

        See linkTo(Frame) for the rules and terminology applying to the linking process.

        Returns:
        true if succeeded otherwise returns false.
        See Also:
        linkTo(Frame), linkFrom(Frame), unlinkFrom(Frame), isLinked(), areLinkedTogether(Frame)

      • unlinkFrom

        public boolean unlinkFrom(Frame requestedFrame)
        Unlinks the requested frame from this frame. Does nothing if the frames are not linked together (areLinkedTogether(Frame)).

        See linkTo(Frame) for the rules and terminology applying to the linking process.

        Returns:
        true if succeeded otherwise returns false.
        See Also:
        linkTo(Frame), linkFrom(Frame), unlink(), isLinked(), areLinkedTogether(Frame)

      • isLinked

        public boolean isLinked()
        Returns true if this frame is linked to a source frame or if this frame acts as the source frame of other frames. Otherwise returns false.

        See linkTo(Frame) for the rules and terminology applying to the linking process.

        See Also:
        linkTo(Frame), linkFrom(Frame), unlink(), unlinkFrom(Frame), areLinkedTogether(Frame)

      • areLinkedTogether

        public boolean areLinkedTogether(Frame sourceFrame)
        Returns true if this frame is linked with sourceFrame. Otherwise returns false.

        See linkTo(Frame) for the rules and terminology applying to the linking process.

        See Also:
        linkTo(Frame), linkFrom(Frame), unlink(), unlinkFrom(Frame), isLinked()

      • setTranslation

        public final void setTranslation(processing.core.PVector t)
        Sets the translation() of the frame, locally defined with respect to the referenceFrame(). Calls modified().

        Use setPosition(PVector) to define the world coordinates position(). Use setTranslationWithConstraint(PVector) to take into account the potential constraint() of the Frame.

        Same as setTranslation(PVector), but if there's a constraint() it is satisfied (without modifying translation).
        See Also:
        setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion), setPositionWithConstraint(PVector)

      • setRotation

        public final void setRotation(Quaternion r)
        Set the current rotation Quaternion and Calls modified(). See the different Quaternion constructors.

        Sets the rotation() of the Frame, locally defined with respect to the referenceFrame().

        Use setOrientation(Quaternion) to define the world coordinates orientation(). The potential constraint() of the Frame is not taken into account, use setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion) instead.

        See Also:
        setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion), rotation(), setTranslation(PVector)

      • setRotationWithConstraint

        public final void setRotationWithConstraint(Quaternion rotation)
        Same as setRotation(Quaternion), if there's a constraint() it's satisfied (without modifying rotation).
        See Also:
        setTranslationWithConstraint(PVector), setOrientationWithConstraint(Quaternion)

      • setReferenceFrame

        public final void setReferenceFrame(Frame rFrame)
        Sets the referenceFrame() of the Frame and calls modified().

        The Frame translation() and rotation() are then defined in the referenceFrame() coordinate system.

        Use position() and orientation() to express these in the world coordinate system.

        Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of Frames. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null referenceFrame()). No action is performed if setting refFrame as the referenceFrame() would create a loop in the Frame hierarchy.

        See Also:
        settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop(Frame)

      • setConstraint

        public void setConstraint(Constraint c)
        Sets the constraint() attached to the Frame.

        A null value means no constraint.

      • settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop

        public final boolean settingAsReferenceFrameWillCreateALoop(Frame frame)
        Returns true if setting frame as the Frame's referenceFrame() would create a loop in the Frame hierarchy.

      • orientation

        public final Quaternion orientation()
        Returns the orientation of the Frame, defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        position(), setOrientation(Quaternion), rotation()

      • setPosition

        public final void setPosition(processing.core.PVector p)
        Sets the position() of the Frame, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setTranslation(PVector) to define the local Frame translation (with respect to the referenceFrame()). The potential constraint() of the Frame is not taken into account, use setPositionWithConstraint(PVector) instead.

        Use setRotation(Quaternion) to define the local frame rotation (with respect to the referenceFrame()). The potential constraint() of the Frame is not taken into account, use setOrientationWithConstraint(Quaternion) instead.

      • translate

        public final void translate(processing.core.PVector t)
        Same as translate(t, true). Calls modified().
        See Also:

      • translate

        public final void translate(processing.core.PVector t,
             boolean keepArg)
        Translates the Frame according to t, locally defined with respect to the referenceFrame(). Calls modified().

        If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the translation actually applied to the Frame may differ from t (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use translate(t, false) to retrieve the filtered translation value and translate(t, true) to keep the original value of t. Use setTranslation(PVector) to directly translate the Frame without taking the constraint() into account.

        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion)

      • translate

        public final void translate(float x,
             float y,
             float z)
        Same as translate(PVector) but with float parameters.

      • rotate

        public final void rotate(Quaternion q)
        Same as rotate(q, true). Calls modified().
        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion, boolean), translate(PVector)

      • rotate

        public final void rotate(Quaternion q,
          boolean keepArg)
        Rotates the Frame by q (defined in the Frame coordinate system): R = R*q. Calls modified().

        If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the rotation actually applied to the Frame may differ from q (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use rotate(q, false) to retrieve the filtered rotation value and rotate(q, true) to keep the original value of q. Use setRotation(Quaternion) to directly rotate the Frame without taking the constraint() into account.

        See Also:
        translate(PVector)

      • rotate

        public final void rotate(float x,
          float y,
          float z,
          float w)
        Same as rotate(Quaternion) but with float Quaternion parameters.

      • rotateAroundPoint

        public final void rotateAroundPoint(Quaternion rotation,
                     processing.core.PVector point)
        Same as rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, true). Calls modified().

      • rotateAroundPoint

        public final void rotateAroundPoint(Quaternion rotation,
                     processing.core.PVector point,
                     boolean keepArg)
        Makes the Frame rotate(Quaternion) by rotation around point. Calls modified().

        point is defined in the world coordinate system, while the rotation axis is defined in the Frame coordinate system.

        If the Frame has a constraint(), rotation is first constrained using Constraint.constrainRotation(Quaternion, Frame). Hence the rotation actually applied to the Frame may differ from rotation (since it can be filtered by the constraint()). Use rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, false) to retrieve the filtered rotation value and rotateAroundPoint(rotation, point, true) to keep the original value of rotation.

        The translation which results from the filtered rotation around point is then computed and filtered using Constraint.constrainTranslation(PVector, Frame).

      • alignWithFrame

        public final void alignWithFrame(Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, false, 0.85f)

      • alignWithFrame

        public final void alignWithFrame(Frame frame,
                  boolean move)
        Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, move, 0.85f)

      • alignWithFrame

        public final void alignWithFrame(Frame frame,
                  float threshold)
        Convenience function that simply calls alignWithFrame(frame, false, threshold)

      • alignWithFrame

        public final void alignWithFrame(Frame frame,
                  boolean move,
                  float threshold)
        Aligns the Frame with frame, so that two of their axis are parallel.

        If one of the X, Y and Z axis of the Frame is almost parallel to any of the X, Y, or Z axis of frame, the Frame is rotated so that these two axis actually become parallel.

        If, after this first rotation, two other axis are also almost parallel, a second alignment is performed. The two frames then have identical orientations, up to 90 degrees rotations.

        threshold measures how close two axis must be to be considered parallel. It is compared with the absolute values of the dot product of the normalized axis.

        When move is set to true, the Frame position() is also affected by the alignment. The new Frame position() is such that the frame frame position (computed with coordinatesOf(PVector), in the Frame coordinates system) does not change.

        frame may be null and then represents the world coordinate system (same convention than for the referenceFrame()).

      • projectOnLine

        public final void projectOnLine(processing.core.PVector origin,
                 processing.core.PVector direction)
        Translates the Frame so that its position() lies on the line defined by origin and direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        Simply uses an orthogonal projection. direction does not need to be normalized.

      • coordinatesOf

        public final processing.core.PVector coordinatesOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the Frame coordinates of a point src defined in the world coordinate system (converts from world to Frame).

        inverseCoordinatesOf(PVector) performs the inverse conversion. transformOf(PVector) converts 3D vectors instead of 3D coordinates.

      • inverseCoordinatesOf

        public final processing.core.PVector inverseCoordinatesOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the world coordinates of the point whose position in the Frame coordinate system is src (converts from Frame to world).

        coordinatesOf(PVector) performs the inverse conversion. Use inverseTransformOf(PVector) to transform 3D vectors instead of 3D coordinates.

      • localCoordinatesOf

        public final processing.core.PVector localCoordinatesOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the Frame coordinates of a point src defined in the referenceFrame() coordinate system (converts from referenceFrame() to Frame).

        localInverseCoordinatesOf(PVector) performs the inverse conversion.

        See Also:
        localTransformOf(PVector)

      • localInverseCoordinatesOf

        public final processing.core.PVector localInverseCoordinatesOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the referenceFrame() coordinates of a point src defined in the Frame coordinate system (converts from Frame to referenceFrame()).

        localCoordinatesOf(PVector) performs the inverse conversion.

        See Also:
        localInverseTransformOf(PVector)

      • coordinatesOfFrom

        public final processing.core.PVector coordinatesOfFrom(processing.core.PVector src,
                                        Frame from)
        Returns the Frame coordinates of the point whose position in the from coordinate system is src (converts from from to Frame).

        coordinatesOfIn(PVector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • coordinatesOfIn

        public final processing.core.PVector coordinatesOfIn(processing.core.PVector src,
                                      Frame in)
        Returns the in coordinates of the point whose position in the Frame coordinate system is src (converts from Frame to in).

        coordinatesOfFrom(PVector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • transformOf

        public final processing.core.PVector transformOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the Frame transform of a vector src defined in the world coordinate system (converts vectors from world to Frame).

        inverseTransformOf(PVector) performs the inverse transformation. coordinatesOf(PVector) converts 3D coordinates instead of 3D vectors (here only the rotational part of the transformation is taken into account).

      • inverseTransformOf

        public final processing.core.PVector inverseTransformOf(processing.core.PVector src)
        Returns the world transform of the vector whose coordinates in the Frame coordinate system is src (converts vectors from Frame to world).

        transformOf(PVector) performs the inverse transformation. Use inverseCoordinatesOf(PVector) to transform 3D coordinates instead of 3D vectors.

      • setXAxis

        public void setXAxis(processing.core.PVector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its xAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system.

        Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(PVector, PVector).

        See Also:
        xAxis(), setYAxis(PVector), setZAxis(PVector)

      • setYAxis

        public void setYAxis(processing.core.PVector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its yAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system.

        Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(PVector, PVector).

        See Also:
        yAxis(), setYAxis(PVector), setZAxis(PVector)

      • setZAxis

        public void setZAxis(processing.core.PVector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its zAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system.

        Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(PVector, PVector).

        See Also:
        zAxis(), setYAxis(PVector), setZAxis(PVector)

      • xAxis

        public processing.core.PVector xAxis()
        Returns the x-axis of the frame, represented as a normalized vector defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setXAxis(PVector), yAxis(), zAxis()

        public processing.core.PVector yAxis()

        See Also:
        setYAxis(PVector), xAxis(), zAxis()

        public processing.core.PVector zAxis()
        Returns the z-axis of the frame, represented as a normalized vector defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setZAxis(PVector), xAxis(), yAxis()

      • localTransformOf

        public final processing.core.PVector localTransformOf(processing.core.PVector src)

        localInverseTransformOf(PVector) performs the inverse transformation.

        See Also:
        localCoordinatesOf(PVector)

      • localInverseTransformOf

        public final processing.core.PVector localInverseTransformOf(processing.core.PVector src)

        localTransformOf(PVector) performs the inverse transformation.

        See Also:
        localInverseCoordinatesOf(PVector)

      • transformOfFrom

        public final processing.core.PVector transformOfFrom(processing.core.PVector src,
                                      Frame from)
        Returns the Frame transform of the vector whose coordinates in the from coordinate system is src (converts vectors from from to Frame).

        transformOfIn(PVector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • transformOfIn

        public final processing.core.PVector transformOfIn(processing.core.PVector src,
                                    Frame in)
        Returns the in transform of the vector whose coordinates in the Frame coordinate system is src (converts vectors from Frame to in).

        transformOfFrom(PVector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

      • matrix

        public final processing.core.PMatrix3D matrix()
        Returns the PMatrix3D associated with this Frame.

        This method could be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify the processing modelview matrix from a Frame hierarchy. For example, with this Frame hierarchy:

        Frame body = new Frame();
        Frame leftArm = new Frame();
        Frame rightArm = new Frame();
        leftArm.setReferenceFrame(body);
        rightArm.setReferenceFrame(body);

        The associated processing drawing code should look like:

        p.pushMatrix();//Supposing p is the PApplet instance
        p.applyMatrix(body.matrix());
        drawBody();
        p.pushMatrix();
        p.applyMatrix(leftArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        p.popMatrix();
        p.pushMatrix();
        p.applyMatrix(rightArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        p.popMatrix();
        p.popMatrix();

        Note the use of nested pushMatrix() and popMatrix() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        Attention: This technique is inefficient because p.applyMatrix will try to calculate the inverse of the transform. Avoid it whenever possible and instead use applyTransformation(PApplet) which is very efficient.

        This matrix only represents the local Frame transformation (i.e., with respect to the referenceFrame()). Use worldMatrix() to get the full Frame transformation matrix (i.e., from the world to the Frame coordinate system). These two match when the referenceFrame() is null.

        The result is only valid until the next call to matrix() or worldMatrix(). Use it immediately (as above).

        Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

        See Also:
        applyTransformation(PApplet)

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(processing.core.PApplet p)
        Convenience wrapper function that simply calls applyTransformation( (PGraphics3D) p.g ).
        See Also:
        applyTransformation(PGraphics3D)

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(processing.core.PGraphics3D p3d)
        Apply the transformation defined by this Frame to p3d. The Frame is first translated and then rotated around the new translated origin.

        Same as:

        p3d.translate(translation().x, translation().y, translation().z);
        p3d.rotate(rotation().angle(), rotation().axis().x, rotation().axis().y, rotation().axis().z);

        This method should be used in conjunction with PApplet to modify the processing modelview matrix from a Frame hierarchy. For example, with this Frame hierarchy:

        Frame body = new Frame();
        Frame leftArm = new Frame();
        Frame rightArm = new Frame();
        leftArm.setReferenceFrame(body);
        rightArm.setReferenceFrame(body);

        The associated processing drawing code should look like:

        p3d.pushMatrix();//p is the PApplet instance
        body.applyTransformation(p);
        drawBody();
        p3d.pushMatrix();
        leftArm.applyTransformation(p);
        drawArm();
        p3d.popMatrix();
        p3d.pushMatrix();
        rightArm.applyTransformation(p);
        drawArm();
        p3d.popMatrix();
        p3d.popMatrix();

        Note the use of nested pushMatrix() and popMatrix() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        Attention: When drawing a frame hierarchy as above, this method should be used whenever possible (one can also use matrix() instead).

        See Also:
        matrix()

      • worldMatrix

        public final processing.core.PMatrix3D worldMatrix()
        Returns the processing transformation matrix represented by the Frame.

        This method should be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify the processing modelview matrix from a Frame:

        // Here the modelview matrix corresponds to the world coordinate system.
        Frame fr = new Frame(pos, Quaternion(from, to));
        pushMatrix();
        applyMatrix(worldMatrix());
        // draw object in the fr coordinate system.
        popMatrix();

        This matrix represents the global Frame transformation: the entire referenceFrame() hierarchy is taken into account to define the Frame transformation from the world coordinate system. Use matrix() to get the local Frame transformation matrix (i.e. defined with respect to the referenceFrame()). These two match when the referenceFrame() is null.

        Attention: The result is only valid until the next call to matrix() or worldMatrix(). Use it immediately (as above).

        Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

      • fromMatrix

        public final void fromMatrix(processing.core.PMatrix3D pM)
        Sets the Frame from a PMatrix3D (processing matrix) representation (rotation in the upper left 3x3 matrix and translation on the last column). Calls modified().

        Hence, if a code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Frame fr = new Frame();
        fr.fromMatrix(m);
        applyMatrix(fr.matrix());

        Using this conversion, you can benefit from the powerful Frame transformation methods to translate points and vectors to and from the Frame coordinate system to any other Frame coordinate system (including the world coordinate system). See coordinatesOf(PVector) and transformOf(PVector).

        Attention: A Frame does not contain a scale factor. The possible scaling in m will not be converted into the Frame by this method.

      • inverse

        public final Frame inverse()
        Returns a Frame representing the inverse of the Frame space transformation.

        The rotation() the new Frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original rotation. Its translation() is the negated inverse rotated image of the original translation.

        If a Frame is considered as a space rigid transformation (translation and rotation), the inverse() Frame performs the inverse transformation.

        Only the local Frame transformation (i.e., defined with respect to the referenceFrame()) is inverted. Use worldInverse() for a global inverse.

        The resulting Frame has the same referenceFrame() as the Frame and a null constraint().

        Note: The scaling factor of the 4x4 matrix is 1.0.

      • worldInverse

        public final Frame worldInverse()
        Returns the inverse() of the Frame world transformation.

        The orientation() of the new Frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original orientation. Its position() is the negated and inverse rotated image of the original position.

        The result Frame has a null referenceFrame() and a null constraint().

        Use inverse() for a local (i.e., with respect to referenceFrame()) transformation inverse.
